During the dot-com boom of the late 1990s and early 2000s, people faced numerous unprecedented business situations that required creative problem-solving. Entrepreneurs frequently pivoted their business models when initial concepts proved unworkable. Companies burned through investment capital rapidly, often hosting lavish launch parties and promotional events to generate buzz.

Recruiters dealt with talent shortages by offering extraordinary compensation packages including substantial stock options. Many professionals job-hopped frequently, chasing better equity packages at promising startups.

When the bubble eventually burst around 2000-2001, survivors generally adopted more conservative approaches, focusing on sustainable business models and realistic growth projections.
